trans-unit.source: How to work with the .NET backend server SDK for Mobile Apps | Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: How to work with the .NET backend server SDK for Mobile Apps | Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure App Service Mobile Apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure App Service Mobile Apps.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use the .NET backend server SDK in key Azure App Service Mobile Apps scenarios.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use the .NET backend server SDK in key Azure App Service Mobile Apps scenarios.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK helps you work with mobile clients from your ASP.NET application.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK helps you work with mobile clients from your ASP.NET application.

trans-unit.source: The SDK is available on [NuGet.org].
trans-unit.target: The SDK is available on [NuGet.org].

trans-unit.source: This package includes the base functionality required to get started using the SDK.
trans-unit.target: This package includes the base functionality required to get started using the SDK.

trans-unit.source: To initialize the SDK, you need to perform actions on the HttpConfiguration object.
trans-unit.target: To initialize the SDK, you need to perform actions on the HttpConfiguration object.

trans-unit.source: To install the SDK, right-click on the server project in Visual Studio, select Manage NuGet Packages, search for the Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server package, then click Install.
trans-unit.target: To install the SDK, right-click on the server project in Visual Studio, select Manage NuGet Packages, search for the Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server package, then click Install.

trans-unit.source: A .NET backend server project is initialized in the Register method of the WebApiConfig class, usually found in the App_Start folder.
trans-unit.target: A .NET backend server project is initialized in the Register method of the WebApiConfig class, usually found in the App_Start folder.

trans-unit.source: An HttpConfiguration object, which represents configuration options for the service, is used to initialize the server project.
trans-unit.target: An HttpConfiguration object, which represents configuration options for the service, is used to initialize the server project.

trans-unit.source: The following example initialize the server project, with no added features:
trans-unit.target: The following example initialize the server project, with no added features:

trans-unit.source: To enable individual features, you must call extension methods on the MobileAppConfiguration object before calling ApplyTo.
trans-unit.target: To enable individual features, you must call extension methods on the MobileAppConfiguration object before calling ApplyTo.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code adds the default routes to all API controllers during initialization:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code adds the default routes to all API controllers during initialization:

trans-unit.source: Many of the feature extension methods are available via additional NuGet packages you can include, which are described in the section below.
trans-unit.target: Many of the feature extension methods are available via additional NuGet packages you can include, which are described in the section below.

trans-unit.source: The following NuGet-based extension packages provide various mobile features that can be used by your application.
trans-unit.target: The following NuGet-based extension packages provide various mobile features that can be used by your application.

trans-unit.source: You enable extensions during initialization by using the MobileAppConfiguration object.
trans-unit.target: You enable extensions during initialization by using the MobileAppConfiguration object.

trans-unit.source: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] Supports the basic Mobile Apps setup.
trans-unit.target: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] Supports the basic Mobile Apps setup.

trans-unit.source: Added to the configuration by calling the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method during initialization.
trans-unit.target: Added to the configuration by calling the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method during initialization.

trans-unit.source: This extension includes following extensions: Notifications, Authentication, Entity, Tables, Crossdomain and Home packages.
trans-unit.target: This extension includes following extensions: Notifications, Authentication, Entity, Tables, Crossdomain and Home packages.

trans-unit.source: This is equivalent to the quickstart server project that you download from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: This is equivalent to the quickstart server project that you download from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Home</linkText><title></title> Adds a simple home page to the web site root.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Home</linkText><title></title> Adds a simple home page to the web site root.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the AddMobileAppHomeController extension method.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the AddMobileAppHomeController extension method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Tables</linkText><title></title> includes classes for working with data and sets-up the data pipeline.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Tables</linkText><title></title> includes classes for working with data and sets-up the data pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the AddTables extension method.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the AddTables extension method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Entity</linkText><title></title> Enables the Entity Framework to access data in the SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Entity</linkText><title></title> Enables the Entity Framework to access data in the SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the AddTablesWithEntityFramework extension method.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the AddTablesWithEntityFramework extension method.

trans-unit.source: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Authentication] Enables authentication and sets-up the OWIN middleware used to validate tokens.
trans-unit.target: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Authentication] Enables authentication and sets-up the OWIN middleware used to validate tokens.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the AddAppServiceAuthentication and IAppBuilder.UseMobileAppAuthentication extension methods.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the AddAppServiceAuthentication and IAppBuilder.UseMobileAppAuthentication extension methods.

trans-unit.source: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications] Enables push notifications and defines a push registration endpoint.
trans-unit.target: [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications] Enables push notifications and defines a push registration endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the AddPushNotifications extension method.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the AddPushNotifications extension method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.CrossDomain</linkText><title></title> Creates a controller that serves data to legacy web browsers from your Mobile App.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.CrossDomain</linkText><title></title> Creates a controller that serves data to legacy web browsers from your Mobile App.

trans-unit.source: Add to the configuration by calling the MapLegacyCrossDomainController extension method.
trans-unit.target: Add to the configuration by calling the MapLegacyCrossDomainController extension method.

trans-unit.source: The custom API controller provides the most basic functionality to your Mobile App backend by exposing an endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The custom API controller provides the most basic functionality to your Mobile App backend by exposing an endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Custom API controller
trans-unit.target: The Custom API controller

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the Controllers folder, then click Add > Controller, select Web API 2 Controller—Empty and click Add.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the Controllers folder, then click Add > Controller, select Web API 2 Controller—Empty and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Supply a Controller name, such as CustomController, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Supply a Controller name, such as CustomController, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: This creates a new CustomController class that inherits from ApiController.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new CustomController class that inherits from ApiController.

trans-unit.source: In the new controller class file, add the following using statement:
trans-unit.target: In the new controller class file, add the following using statement:

trans-unit.source: Apply the MobileAppControllerAttribute to the API controller class definition, as in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Apply the MobileAppControllerAttribute to the API controller class definition, as in the following example:

trans-unit.source: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the MapApiControllers extension method, as in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the MapApiControllers extension method, as in the following example:

trans-unit.source: Note that you do not need to call MapApiControllers when you call UseDefaultConfiguration, which initializes all features.
trans-unit.target: Note that you do not need to call MapApiControllers when you call UseDefaultConfiguration, which initializes all features.

trans-unit.source: Any controller that does not have MobileAppControllerAttribute applied can still be accessed by clients, but it will not be correctly consumed by clients using any Mobile App client SDK.
trans-unit.target: Any controller that does not have MobileAppControllerAttribute applied can still be accessed by clients, but it will not be correctly consumed by clients using any Mobile App client SDK.

trans-unit.source: A table controller provides access to entity data in a table-based data store, such as SQL Database or Azure Table storage.
trans-unit.target: A table controller provides access to entity data in a table-based data store, such as SQL Database or Azure Table storage.

trans-unit.source: Table controllers inherit from the TableController generic class, where the generic type is an entity in the model that represents the table schema, as follows:
trans-unit.target: Table controllers inherit from the TableController generic class, where the generic type is an entity in the model that represents the table schema, as follows:

trans-unit.source: Table controllers are initialized by using the AddTables extension method.
trans-unit.target: Table controllers are initialized by using the AddTables extension method.

trans-unit.source: The following example initializes a table controller that uses Entity Framework for data access:
trans-unit.target: The following example initializes a table controller that uses Entity Framework for data access:

trans-unit.source: For an example of a table controller that uses Entity Framework to access data from an Azure SQL Database, see the TodoItemController class in the quickstart server project download from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: For an example of a table controller that uses Entity Framework to access data from an Azure SQL Database, see the TodoItemController class in the quickstart server project download from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: You can add authentication to your server project by extending the MobileAppConfiguration object and configuring OWIN middleware.
trans-unit.target: You can add authentication to your server project by extending the MobileAppConfiguration object and configuring OWIN middleware.

trans-unit.source: When you install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] package and call the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method, you can skip to step 4.
trans-unit.target: When you install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] package and call the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method, you can skip to step 4.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Authentication] package.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Authentication] package.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the AddAppServiceAuthentication extension method during initialization, which looks like the following:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the AddAppServiceAuthentication extension method during initialization, which looks like the following:

trans-unit.source: In the Startup.cs project file,aAdd the following line of code at the beginning of the Configuration method:
trans-unit.target: In the Startup.cs project file,aAdd the following line of code at the beginning of the Configuration method:

trans-unit.source: This adds the OWIN middleware component that enables your Azure Mobile App to validate tokens issued by the associated App Service gateway.
trans-unit.target: This adds the OWIN middleware component that enables your Azure Mobile App to validate tokens issued by the associated App Service gateway.

trans-unit.source: Add the [Authorize] attribute to any controller or method that requires authentication.
trans-unit.target: Add the [Authorize] attribute to any controller or method that requires authentication.

trans-unit.source: Users must now be authenticated to access that endpoint or those a specific APIs.
trans-unit.target: Users must now be authenticated to access that endpoint or those a specific APIs.

trans-unit.source: To learn about how to authenticate clients to your Mobile Apps backend, see <linkText>Add authentication to your app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn about how to authenticate clients to your Mobile Apps backend, see <linkText>Add authentication to your app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can add push notifications to your server project by extending the MobileAppConfiguration object and creating a Notification Hubs client.
trans-unit.target: You can add push notifications to your server project by extending the MobileAppConfiguration object and creating a Notification Hubs client.

trans-unit.source: When you install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] package and call the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method, you can skip down to step 3.
trans-unit.target: When you install the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart] package and call the UseDefaultConfiguration extension method, you can skip down to step 3.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the server project and click Manage NuGet Packages, search for Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications`, then click Install.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the server project and click Manage NuGet Packages, search for Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications`, then click Install.

trans-unit.source: This installs the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications] package.
trans-unit.target: This installs the [Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications] package.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this step to install the Microsoft.Azure.NotificationHubs package, which includes the Notification Hubs client library.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this step to install the Microsoft.Azure.NotificationHubs package, which includes the Notification Hubs client library.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the AddPushNotifications extension method during initialization, which looks like the following:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the App_Startup folder, open the WebApiConfig.cs project file and add a call to the AddPushNotifications extension method during initialization, which looks like the following:

trans-unit.source: This creates the push notification registration endpoint in your server project.
trans-unit.target: This creates the push notification registration endpoint in your server project.

trans-unit.source: This endpoint is used by clients to register with the associated notification hub.
trans-unit.target: This endpoint is used by clients to register with the associated notification hub.

trans-unit.source: Now you need to add the Notification Hub client that is used to send notifications.
trans-unit.target: Now you need to add the Notification Hub client that is used to send notifications.

trans-unit.source: In a controller from which you want to send push notifications, add the following using statement:
trans-unit.target: In a controller from which you want to send push notifications, add the following using statement:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code that creates a Notification Hubs client:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code that creates a Notification Hubs client:

trans-unit.source: At this point, you can use the Notification Hubs client to send push notifications to registered devices.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you can use the Notification Hubs client to send push notifications to registered devices.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Add push notifications to your app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Add push notifications to your app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about all that you can do with Notification Hubs, see <linkText>Notification Hubs Overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about all that you can do with Notification Hubs, see <linkText>Notification Hubs Overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to publish your server project to Azure:
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to publish your server project to Azure:

trans-unit.target: http://www.nuget.org/

trans-unit.target: http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Quickstart/

trans-unit.target: http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Authentication/

trans-unit.target: http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.Mobile.Server.Notifications/
